required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Family Matters Intervention: Targeting Family Meals Using Technology to Reduce Childhood Obesity
clinical_study.official_title: Using State-of-the-Art Intervention Methods During Family Mealtimes and Partnerships With Primary Care to Reduce Childhood Obesity

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

clinical_study.source: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

brief_summary.textblock: This childhood obesity randomized controlled trial uses innovative methods, such as video feedback and ecological momentary intervention (EMI) to compare a family meals coaching intervention to a usual care condition in racially/ethnically diverse children ages 5-7 years and their families. The intervention utilizes in-home visiting methods targeting family meal quantity and quality delivered across a three-phased incremental 18-month period compared to obesity prevention messages delivered during well-child visits and monthly newsletters.

detailed_description.textblock:
The main objective of the current study is to utilize state-of-the art methods and intervention techniques (i.e., EMI, video feedback, in-home visiting) in partnership with primary care to examine whether increasing the quantity and quality of family meals reduces childhood obesity. An individual randomized controlled trial (RCT) will be conducted with socioeconomically and racially/ethnically diverse children ages 5-7 years at high risk for obesity (BMI ≥75%ile, or ≥50th%ile and parent BMI ≥ 25) and their families. Families will be randomly assigned to the family meals coaching (FMC) intervention or usual care. There will be three incremental phases of the 18-month intervention: (1) Interactive Learning (6 months; 12 in-home visits); (2) Making Changes (6 months; 8 in-home visits); and (3) Maintenance (6 months; 6 phone calls). Using in-home visits, video feedback about family meal behaviors (e.g., dietary healthfulness, parent feeding practices, interpersonal atmosphere), daily EMI prompts via smartphones, and well-child visits in primary care, families in FMC will be supported to increase the quantity and quality of family meals. The phases progressively provide less support for families to increase self-efficacy and sustainability of new behaviors. Usual care will include obesity prevention messages delivered at well-child visits (i.e., 5-2-1-0)44 and monthly mailings. Outcomes will be assessed at the end of each phase (6 months, 12 months), post-intervention (18 months) and 6 months post-intervention (24 months).
Aim 1: Conduct an RCT comparing the family meals coaching (FMC) intervention to usual care in racially/ethnically diverse children ages 5-7 and their families to test the hypotheses that:
Hypothesis 1: Family meal quantity and quality will significantly increase in households with children in the FMC condition compared to children in the usual care condition.
Hypothesis 2: Children in the FMC condition will significantly increase their diet quality and reduce their BMI%ile compared to children in the usual care condition.
Hypothesis 3: Parents in the FMC condition will show significant reductions in restriction and pressure-to-eat feeding practices as compared to parents in the usual care condition.
Aim 2: Examine intervention "spillover" effects in other family members exposed to the intervention.
Hypothesis 1: Family members in the FMC condition will significantly reduce their BMI/BMI%ile and increase healthful weight-related behaviors compared to family members in the usual care condition.
Aim 3: Measure the cost-effectiveness of delivering the intervention via Patient Centered Medical Homes PCMHs.
Hypothesis 1: The BMI%ile reduction resulting from the FMC intervention will be cost-effective.

primary_outcome.description: Family meal frequency as measured by a self-report survey item at three time points over 24 months.
Family meal dietary quality as measured by the Healthfulness of Meal (HOM) index via video-recorded direct observation at three time points over 24 months.
Family meal emotional atmosphere quality as measured by the Iowa Family Interaction Rating Scales (IFIRS) via video-recorded direct observation at three time points over 24 months.

secondary_outcome.description: Based on Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines, child age and sex adjusted BMI percentiles. Measured at three time points over 24 months.

other_outcome.description: Child 3-day, 24-hour dietary recalls measured by the Healthy Eating Index (HEI) at three time points over 24 months.

arm_group.description: The Family Matters experimental arm uses obesity prevention messages (i.e., 5-2-1-0 messages) delivered during well-child visits, ecological momentary intervention, video feedback and home visiting to increase family meal quality and quantity. The intervention will be delivered to racially/ethnically and socioeconomically diverse children ages 5-7 years at high risk for obesity (i.e., child BMI ≥75%ile or ≥ 50th%ile and parent ≥ 25 BMI) and their families over an 18-month time period. The intervention will be delivered using an incremental three-phased approach (i.e., Interactive Learning, Making Changes, Maintenance), allowing for progressively less support for families to increase self-efficacy and sustainability behaviors. Eligible children will be recruited through primary care clinics serving a high proportion of children at high-risk for obesity, including minority (i.e., African American, Native American, Hispanic) and low-income populations.

The usual care arm uses obesity prevention messages (i.e., 5-2-1-0 messages) delivered during well-child visits and a monthly mailed newsletter on general child health issues. Usual care will be delivered to racially/ethnically and socioeconomically diverse children ages 5-7 years at high risk for obesity (i.e., child BMI ≥75%ile or ≥ 50th%ile and parent ≥ 25 BMI) and their families over an 18-month time period. Eligible children will be recruited through primary care clinics serving a high proportion of children at high-risk for obesity, including minority (i.e., African American, Native American, Hispanic) and low-income populations.

intervention.description: The experimental arm includes three incremental phases over 18 months. Phase I includes 12 bi-weekly in-home visits that last 90 mins. facilitated by a behavioral health and dietitian team. Meal quality and quantity will be targeted. The primary caregiver will also receive daily EMI messages about increasing meal quantity and quality via a smartphone, based on the stress level reported earlier in the day. Phase II visits will occur every 3 weeks over 6 months. Daily EMI prompts will continue and video feedback will be introduced. In between visits, families will video-record via an iPad at least 3 family dinner meals. Family meal coaches will watch the videos in between home visits to identify specific footage to show family members at the next in-home visit that highlights both positive and negative family interactions and diet quality patterns. During Phase III, parents will receive monthly booster phone calls for six months. The EMI and the video feedback will discontinue.

The usual care condition will receive childhood obesity prevention messages (i.e., 5-2-1-0) from primary care providers and monthly newsletters focusing on general child health. All clinics in the study already use 5-2-1-0 messages for childhood obesity prevention. These are evidence-based messages (i.e., 5 fruits and vegetables/day; no more than 2 hours of screen time/day; at least 1 hour of physical activity/day; 0 sugar-sweetened beverages/day) that providers share with parents during well-child visits. The monthly newsletters will cover general child health issues, such as car seat safety, immunizations, etc.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: The inclusionary criteria used to select participants includes:
- Boys and girls ages 5-7 years old who attend a University of Minnesota or Fairview primary care clinic, their primary caregiver, and at least one other family member.
- ≤3 family dinner meals per week: observational research has shown that youth who have three or more family meals per week are less likely to be obese ten years later. Thus, we will recruit families who report three or fewer family dinner meals per week in order to optimize the potential for change in family dinner meal frequency. We will use "family dinners" as the definition of family meals because the majority of families report having family dinners compared to breakfast or lunch family meals.
- At-risk for childhood obesity, including: (1) age and gender adjusted BMI ≥75th percentile or (2) age and gender adjusted BMI ≥50th percentile and at least one parent with a body mass index (BMI) ≥25.
- One of the following race/ethnicities: Hispanic/Latino, African American, American Indian, or White.
- Speak English or Spanish.
Exclusion Criteria. The exclusionary criteria used to select participants includes:
- Children with special dietary, physical, or behavioral needs.
- Non-custodial parents.
